content.description:
Fun ridge, then thoughtful slab. . . . (Add a fun inside corner, if do Variation).

 Start on ridge / outside-corner which forms the right edge of the obvious low 16-inch-deep left-facing inside corner at the right end of this cliff. Up the ridge / outside corner to stand up on wide ledge / platform.  . . . Variation: Start up inside corner and its left side to stand up on wide ledge / platform (without using holds on the right-side ridge, but right-side inside face is OK).

 Next straight up short face and onto slab (crux). Finish left-ward up slab.

warning: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber or someone setting up top anchor.

 . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2018. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

 FA style + Naming of routes: For more on this - - > See the Main page for Cranberry Hollow.
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up anchor for Top-Roping, see the Description page for this sector.

 Protection for trad Leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
Ridge / outside-corner which forms the right edge of the obvious low 16-inch-deep left-facing inside corner at the right end of this cliff.

content.description:
Thoughtful sustained crux sequence, following a fun lower-half warmup. . . . (or two fun lower-half warmups, if also do the Variation).

 Start under high 1-ft-deep left-facing inside corner. . . . Variation: Start on face to right, halfway between this high corner and the obvious low left-facing inside corner at the right end of this cliff.

 Up to the base of the high corner. Then up to the top (perhaps easier along R side of corner?), with a tricky exit.

warning: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber or someone setting up top anchor.

 . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2018. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Some fun moves. Too bad it's not longer.

 Start on the ridge which forms the right edge of the obvious gully near the left end of this cliff. Up the ridge to its top. Scramble a bit, then finish to right of obvious high perched rock.

warning: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber or someone setting up top anchor.

 . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2018. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Some thoughtful moves. Too bad it's not longer.

 Start on face just right of the obvious gully near the left end of this cliff. Up the face, without touching any rock inside the gully - (do not use the left edge/corner of ridge). After that lower off, or finish up the Left Ridge route.

warning: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber or someone setting up top anchor.

content.description:
Thoughtful outdoor-style moves the whole way. If only this were longer.

 Start at the bottom of the obvious Left-slanting gully in the center of the wall. Up the gully diagonal, then straight up to 6-inch-thick tree at top of cliff.

warning: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber or someone setting up top anchor.

 . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2018. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Some fun overhanging moves, then easier slab - (Too bad the overhanging part is not longer).

 Start on the short overhanging face to the right of the obvious low 16-inch-deep left-facing inside corner at the right end of this cliff. Up the face to stand up on wide ledge / platform. Next up around right onto slab, then left up slab to its top. . . . (or finish on the route to left of this one).

warning: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber or someone setting up top anchor.

 . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2018. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Some interesting moves.

 Start about 6 ft left of the bottom of obvious central gully, Straight up to the perched triangular block (without using smaller lower block jammed in the gully about 8 ft up. Around left side of both perched blocks. Finish over upturned nose which is left from below 6-inch-thick tree at top of cliff.

warning: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber or someone setting up top anchor.

 . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2018. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
First 15 feet rather tricky especially if much less tall than 5ft9inch with normal reach. Then the rest is much easier (but with some fun moves).

 Start about 10 ft left of the bottom of obvious central gully, about 5 ft right of 1-ft-deep small roof 12 ft up. Up 5 ft, horizontal Left 5 ft, then up 5 ft hard. After that finish to left side of upturned nose which is left from below 6-inch-thick tree at top of cliff.

 . . . Variation Start: Instead start to the left under right side of the small roof.

warning: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber or someone setting up top anchor.

 . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2018. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
One hard sequence. Exact difficulty uncertain, since no one has yet put together all the individual moves as of 2018.

 Start under left side of small 1-ft-deep roof 12 ft up. Up around left side of roof, next traverse right five feet to reach positive left-facing flake, then up.

warning: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber or someone setting up top anchor.

 . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2018. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

 - - > See on this Photo

content.description:
25-35 ft routes around vertical on fun featured granite or granitic gneiss. Faces WSW (so good bet for afternoon on a cool day). Much is shaded by mature trees, so not as hot as might expect on hot afternoons.

 Straightforward access on official maintained trail then unofficial "herd paths".

 A bit south from the true "hollow" so a bit more noise than some other sectors. Some swampy land near the base, so likely more insects than some other sectors -- could be better after it's been dry for a while.

 Lots more climbing nearby at sector Benes, just above SE.

 Top-Roping: Obvious way to reach the top of this cliff to set up a top anchor is to scramble up around the right (south) side - (but likely also works to up around the left / north side).

 Name: Nicholas Clifford started the Princeton Mountaineering Club, and pioneered new routes at Delaware Water Gap in bold style before anything like modern protection. Later made first ascents of high + wild peaks in Alaska. Likely did the first climbing at Â the big cliffs overlooking Green Pond Rd, NJ.

First Ascents? When we started exploring this rock sector, we discovered lots of previous work (cleaning + cutting) to prepare the rock and cliff top and base and approaches for climbing. So we could focus on just trying different possible routes for climbing. Whoever did that work, please contact us so we can give proper credit for your First Ascents.

warning: Loose rock is still a concern in this sector. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber or underneath a leader setting up top anchor.

 . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2018. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
